facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1171 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1171 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 27, 1966 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 195 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 27, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Appellate Decree No. 195 of 1964.

facts.text: Respondent employed as motor driver in Airways India Ltd prior to August 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to August 1953, the respondent was employed as a motor driver in Airways  India  Ltd.

facts.text: Air Corporation Act XXVII of 1953 passed and Airways India Ltd taken over by appellant-Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: On the passing of the Air Corporation Act, XXVII of 1953, and companysequent thereupon of the taking over of the existing air companypanies, including the Airways  India  Ltd., by the appellant- Corporation,

facts.text: Respondent became employee of appellant-Corporation after takeover.

anchor.surface_text: he became the employee of the appellant- Corporation.

facts.text: Respondent suspended on January 13, 1956 on certain charges.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1956, he was suspended on certain charges.

facts.text: Respondent found guilty after enquiry and dismissed by order dated February 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On being found guilty of those charges after an enquiry had been held, he was dismissed by an order dated February 6, 1956.

facts.text: Respondent filed suit alleging enquiry breached procedure in Regulations under sec. 45 of the Act, dismissal illegal and void.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a suit alleging that the enquiry had been companyducted in breach of the procedure laid down by the Regulations made by the Corporation under sec. 45 of the Act, and that therefore, the dismissal was illegal and void.

facts.text: Trial Court accepted contention and granted declaration that service continued as dismissal null and void.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court accepted the companytention and granted a declaration that his service companytinued as the order dismissing him was null and void.

facts.text: First appellate court upheld Trial Court's decree.

anchor.surface_text: That decree was upheld by the first appellate companyrt.

facts.text: High Court in second appeal conceded Regulations applied and procedure not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: In a second appeal in the High Court, it was companyceded that the Regulations applied to the respondents case, and that the procedure therein laid down for terminating his service was number companyplied with.

facts.text: Corporation contended only damages entitled, not declaration.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporations companytention, however, was that the only relief to which the respondent was entitled to was damages and that a declaration, such as the one granted by the Trial Court, companyld number be given.

facts.text: High Court rejected Corporation's contention and held dismissal illegal, service continues.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected that companytention holding, that the Corporation was under a statutory obligation to observe the procedure laid down in the Regulations, and that number having been done, the order of dismissal was illegal and void and the respondent companytinued to be in the employment of the Corporation as if there was numbertermination of service.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, founded on a certificate granted by the High Court, is directed against its aforesaid judgement and decree.

facts.text: Admitted fact that respondent's service terminated in breach of procedural safeguards in Regulations.

anchor.surface_text: It being an admitted fact that the respondents service was terminated in breach of the procedural safeguards provided in the Regulations,

facts.text: Air Corporation Act XXVII of 1953 set up appellant-Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The fact, therefore, that the appellant-Corporation was one set up under and was regulated by Act XXVII of 1953

facts.text: Section 20 of Air Corporation Act provides employees of existing companies become employees of Corporation on appointed date with same terms until altered.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 20 provides that Every officer or other employee of an existing air companypany-employed by that companypany prior to the first day of July, 1952, and still in its employment immediately before the appointed date shall-become as from the appointed date an officer or other employee, as the case may be, of the Corporation in which the undertaking has vested and shall hold his office or service therein by the same tenure, at the same remuneration and upon the same terms and companyditions and with the same rights and privileges as to pensions and gratuity and other matters as he would have held the same under the existing air companypany if its undertaking had number vested in the Cor- poration and shall companytinue to do so unless and until his employment in the Corporation is terminated or until his remuneration, terms or companyditions are duly altered by the Corporation.

facts.text: Corporations have power under sec. 45 to make regulations on terms and conditions of service with Central Government approval.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 45 authorises each of the two Corporations with the approval of the Central Government and by numberification in the Government gazette to make regulations number inconsistent with the Act or the rules made under s. 44 for the administration of the affairs of the Corporation and for carrying out its functions and in particular providing the terms and companyditions of service of officers and other employees of the Corporation other than the general manager and officers of any other categories referred to in s. 44.

facts.text: Supreme Court held declaration should not be granted, only damages, as master-servant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: The present case, therefore, did number fall under an of the three well recognized excep- tions, and therefore, the respondent was only entitled to damages and number to the declaration that his dismissal was null and void.

facts.text: No statutory restriction in Act or rules on termination power, only in regulations.

anchor.surface_text: neither the Act number the rules made under sec. 44 by the Central Government lay down any obligation or restriction as to the power of the Corporation to terminate the employment of its employees or any procedural safeguards, subject to which only, such power companyld be exercised.
The respondent filed a suit alleging that the enquiry had been conducted in breach of the procedure laid down by the Regulations made by the Corporation under sec. 45 of the Act,

One exception where declaration possible: public servants protected by Art.311(2); this case not applicable.
Second exception to no-declaration rule; not applicable here.
Third exception: breach of mandatory statutory (not regulatory) obligation; regulations here not mandatory statutory restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: Cases of dismissal fall into three classes, said Lord Reid in Ridge v. Baldwin. firstly, dismissal of a servant by his master, secondly, dismissal from office held during pleasure, and thirdly, dismissal from office where there must be something against a man to warrant his dismissal.

concepts.interpretation: Hearing required only in third category (statutory offices); not in pure master-servant.

That was a case of lack of power in the Board to delegate its disciplinary function to a committee which dismissed the employee-an action which was held ultra vires,

concepts.interpretation: Dismissal ultra vires = nullity; not applicable here as power existed.

issues.text: the question for determination is whether in cases, such as the one before us, a declaration given by the Trial Court and upheld by the High Court could be granted

anchor.surface_text: It being an admitted fact that the respondents service was terminated in breach of the procedural safeguards provided in the Regulations, the question for determination is whether in cases, such as the one before us, a declaration given by the Trial Court and upheld by the High Court could be granted.

arguments.court_reasoning: No obligation or restriction in Act or rules; safeguards only in regulations which are contractual

arguments.claim: When there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration that the contract still subsists would not be made absent special circumstances as courts do not grant specific performance of service contracts even if appointment by statutory authority

anchor.surface_text: It is a well settled principle that when there is a purported termination of a contract of service, a declaration, that the contract of service still subsisted, would not be made in the absence of special circumstances because of the principle that courts do not ordinarily grant specific performance of service.

arguments.claim: Dismissals fall into three classes and right to hearing arises only where authority is under statutory restriction as to contract or grounds of dismissal; pure master-servant no hearing required

anchor.surface_text: Cases of dismissal fall into three classes, said Lord Reid in Ridge v. Baldwin... Such a question of being heard or not can only arise where the authority employing the servant is under some statutory or other restriction as to the kind of contract which it can make with its servants or the grounds on which it can dismiss them.

arguments.claim: No statutory limitation or obligation restricting Corporation's power to terminate service except by complying with such obligation; relationship is master-servant

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, would be whether the relationship between the Corporation and the respondent was any thing else than that of master and servant, or whether the Corporation was under some statutory limitation or obligation by reason of which it could not terminate his service except by complying with such an obligation.

arguments.claim: Act does not impose statutory restriction or obligation limiting power to terminate employment; no procedural safeguards in Act or rules under s.44

anchor.surface_text: neither the Act nor the rules made under sec. 44 by the Central Government lay down any obligation or restriction as to the power of the Corporation to terminate the employment of its employees or any procedural safeguards, subject to which only, such power could be exercised.

arguments.claim: Present case does not fall under any of the three exceptions to master-servant rule where declaration granted: not Art.311 public servant, not industrial law, not breach of mandatory statutory obligation
Regulations made under s.45 merely embody terms and conditions of service, do not constitute statutory restriction on contracts or termination grounds
Life Insurance Corporation v. Mukherjee supports claim for declaration of invalid dismissal
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishable: govt order under s.11(2) imposed mandatory procedure; regulations subject to it; here no equivalent order or statutory override

arguments.claim: Case analogous to S.R. Tewari v. District Board Agra and U.P. State Warehousing Corporation v. Tyagi where breach of regulations entitles only to damages, not declaration
Regulations and Central Govt order in LIC Mukherjee must be read harmoniously; termination without following order invalid - but not applicable here

anchor.surface_text: The order declaring the dismissal invalid thus was based on the ground that the regulations and the Order of the Central Government must be read harmoniously and when so read, the Central Governments Order gave power to terminate the service

holdings.text: The respondent was only entitled to damages and not to the declaration that his dismissal was null and void.

anchor.surface_text: The present case, therefore, did number fall under an of the three well recognized excep- tions, and therefore, the respondent was only entitled to damages and number to the declaration that his dismissal was null and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal in breach of regulations but pure master-servant relationship; does not fall under any of three exceptions (Art 311, industrial law, mandatory statutory obligation); follows S.R. Tewari and U.P. Warehousing.

holdings.text: Neither the Act nor the rules made under sec. 44 lay down any obligation or restriction as to the power of the Corporation to terminate the employment of its employees or any procedural safeguards.

anchor.surface_text: neither the Act number the rules made under sec. 44 by the Central Government lay down any obligation or restriction as to the power of the Corporation to terminate the employment of its employees or any procedural safeguards, subject to which only, such power companyld be exercised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of Air Corporations Act ss.8,20,44; procedural safeguards only in regulations under s.45, not statute.

holdings.text: Regulations made under s.45 merely embody terms and conditions of service but do not constitute a statutory restriction as to contracts or grounds of termination.

anchor.surface_text: Though made under the power companyferred by the statute, they merely embody the terms and companyditions of service in the Corporation but do number companystitute a statutory restriction as to the kind of companytracts which the Corporation can make with its servants or the grounds on which it can terminate them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulations lack public force of law per Kruse v. Johnson; contractual like university cases; distinguished from bye-laws with penalties.

holdings.text: The relationship between the Corporation and its employees is purely that of master and servant.

anchor.surface_text: The fact, therefore, that the appellant-Corporation was one set up under and was regulated by Act XXVII of 1953 would number take away, without anything more, the relationship between it and its employees from the category of purely master and servant relationship.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory corporation regulated by Act does not alter master-servant relation absent specific restrictions; follows Vidyodaya University v. Silva.

holdings.text: The present case does not fall under any of the three well recognized exceptions to the general rule under master-servant law where declaration of continuance would be granted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not public servant under Art.311; not industrial law; no mandatory statutory (only regulatory) obligation breached; applies S.R. Tewari framework.
